If they reverse time, then no one will notice that half the world died, and things wouldn‚Äôt seem weird afterward in Spider-Man FFH. It will be like nothing happened, which is what the trailer kind of entails it‚Äôs like. Although, then again, they didn‚Äôt want to spoil anything from Endgame in the FFH trailer. The other most popular theory I‚Äôve heard is that everyone who died was actually just stuck in the time stone. Apparently, this is what happened in the comics. Or one of the versions of the comics (the comic story-line confuses me). People I don‚Äôt know about surviving are Gamora and Loki. I definitely do think Loki is dead and will remain that way but idk about Gamora because I know there‚Äôs a new Guardians of The Galaxy movie coming out. It would be weird to have one of those movies without her I feel so idk if they are really gonna do that. One thing that confused me is apparently, Shuri is dead. Or ‚Äúdead,‚Äù but the actress, Letitia Wright, said that Shuri was still alive in an interview I read a while ago. According to the trailer though, Shuri is dead. But as I said, I think they will all come back.

content.text: Unfortunately, I got cut off by the blue screen of death on my computer during my hopes and predictions writing, so I never really finished everything I had to say before the movie. But now I‚Äôve watched the movie twice now, and here‚Äôs what I thought.

I think the movie was definitely better than the first one. Maybe I‚Äôm biased because Zendaya was barely in the first one but she‚Äôs in this one a lot, but there were more action scenes, more humor and I think the villain was more interesting. I liked the idea of illusion tech with drones for real destruction. The movie did take longer to get to the climax, but once it did, it got really fun (not that it wasn‚Äôt fun before). No character died, which is something a lot of people were predicting, so that was nice. Well, actually Mysterio died I guess, but some people are predicting that he‚Äôs not really dead. They say it‚Äôs just another illusion of his. Idk, so we‚Äôll see, I guess. I was right about Mysterio being the bad guy though. I didn‚Äôt trust him the whole movie and about halfway through, I was right, he is not the guy to trust. He was the main villain. Hydro-Man and all the other ones were just illusions made by Mysterio that looked really real. There was also no such thing as the elementals, and I guess the multiverse was also a lie. Idk if I had time to mention the elementals and multiverse from the trailer in my pre-writing, but yeah‚Ä¶it was all a lie. I‚Äôm just realizing, in my dream last night, I had a book about grammar that I was reading. Hmm interesting. Anyway, Ned and Betty did get together, but then they broke up at the end of the movie (LOL), but Peter and MJ starting dating at the end. MJ also admitted that she knew about Peter being Spider-Man for a while, and she mentioned the Washington Monument, so I guess she put two and two together back in the first movie. Although, she said she was only 67% sure until he admitted it.

What me and a lot of other people liked about Peter and MJ‚Äôs relationship is that MJ didn‚Äôt have to change in order for Peter to like her. It wasn‚Äôt like in the first movie she was this sarcastic, nerdy and awkward character and then she evolves into a ‚Äúpretty‚Äù, social and romantic character or something so then Peter starts crushing on her. She was still sarcastic, nerdy and awkward in FFH and Peter liked her for that. Peter is nerdy and awkward himself so he had that relationship to MJ so he started liking her. It‚Äôs a lot more realistic and had a much better message. I also liked how Peter stayed realistic to a high school student the whole time. He was constantly doubting himself, downplaying himself, just wanting to tell a girl he likes that he likes her, buying the girl he likes a gift, using Edith to resolve high school drama, prioritizing liking a girl more than super-hero stuff‚Ä¶.you know, it‚Äôs just the movie keeps Peter very realistic to a high school kid the whole time and I love that.

I got the ‚Äúunexpected ending‚Äù part though. It was that Peter‚Äôs identity was revealed to the world by Mysterio and his crew. Yeah, it was pretty unexpected. I wonder if the next Marvel movies to come out will address that or if it‚Äôs not until Spider-Man 3 when we find out how this worldwide revelation affects Peter. But I might not be alive to see Spider-Man 3. It‚Äôs okay, I‚Äôm good enough with Spider-Man FFH. And I‚Äôm just glad the ending didn‚Äôt have to do with someone dying or MJ being a bad guy or Nick Fury being MJ‚Äôs father or something like that. Those were some predictions. Watching the movie made me realize how good Marvel is at keeping their movies underwraps. There are all these predictions all the time and you start thinking, ‚Äúmann, these guys gotta be right,‚Äù or ‚Äúthat actually sounds like it could be legit,‚Äù but then like all predictions are way off. No one saw the elementals and multiverse being fake coming and no one saw Peter being revealed coming. I sensed that Mysterio was the bad guy and I believe many others did too, but I think also, a lot of people were fooled by the trailer and interviews. Like Marvel is just good at what they do. Every movie series should aspire to be like them.
Here‚Äôs some predictions for FFH that were wrong though.
They were not mainly in London and the trip was not about anything for Stark Industries
There was no MI6 agent
There was no one names Alistair ‚Äì I think they meant Brad
Liz was not in the movie
J.B. Smoove did not play J. Jonah Jameson
Cinema Sins:

1. Someone had to see Peter running around trying to destroy Hydro-Man in Venice without his suit. I mean really, no one just saw this guy swinging from buildings in the complete public and didn‚Äôt take their phone out to take a photo or video? I know a lot of them were running for their lives, but still, this is 2019.

2. I know that Peter has super strength, but he doesn‚Äôt have invincibility, or a body made out of metal. When he hit the church bell hard with his head twice, he definitely should have had scars and have been knocked out for a while.
3. How come the illusion tech that MJ found didn‚Äôt go off when she was putting it in her bag, but it went off when she took it out to show Peter?

4. Mysterio did not transfer all files and security stuff on Edith back to Peter so how is Peter able to use Edith again after beating Mysterio, as if he was the owner? Since he gave it to Mysterio, Mysterio should need to give him permission and confirmation like Peter did, right?

5. You‚Äôre telling me no one died from the drones (other than Mysterio) during all the destruction? Not one person from the carnival and not one person from the scene in London? Mysterio even said there will be a lot of casualities, but when Peter was walking around after beating Mysterio, there were no dead bodies to be seen.
6. Why would Peter have walked around in his Spider-Man outfit without the head mask on after beating Mysterio? I know it was to make a cute moment with MJ, but anyone could have run up and seen him.
7. How tf did MJ even find Peter? I mean he could have been anywhere.
8. If Nick Fury is so paranoid than why would he let a skrull take over for him on such a major mission?
9. How was Happy confident that Nick Fury had got his coded message? What if Nick Fury hadn‚Äôt got it?

Well, I watched Endgame last night. Lemme say it really was like the best movie ever. OBVIOUSLY, DON‚ÄôT READ THIS IF YOU HAVEN‚ÄôT WATCHED ENDGAME YET‚ö† It was amazing, and that‚Äôs coming from someone who hasn‚Äôt even seen half of the MCU movies. It just had a sense of closure and so even without knowing the whole story, I got what was going on and how meaningful each part was. Especially after reading comments after the movie from people who had seen more/all the movies. I didn‚Äôt finish my pre-Endgame writing in time bc I had a lot to do yesterday, but‚Ä¶‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know where I was going with that. I was just informing, I guess.

Iron Man did die as expected, but I still don‚Äôt know why that Ask FM guy had to be an asshole. I‚Äôm still not gonna respond to him. Iron Man died nobly at the very end though. It was because he snapped his fingers with the stones and being just human, he wasn‚Äôt strong enough to take it. Tom Holland amazed us all with his acting again at the Iron Man dying scene, which brings me to another one of my predictions coming true. All the heroes did indeed come back. All except Loki, who was gone as expected, but I‚Äôm not actually sure about Gamora. Gamora died and can‚Äôt come back, but since they went back in time and then went to the future, Gamora from the past is now living in the future and I guess has no recollection to anything that happened in the last years (Idk the exact count, but it has to have been a while).

Basically, how they beat Thanos and fixed everything was that they went back in time. Although, not as I or very many people predicted. Instead of using the stones to go back in time, they used the Quantum Realm. I totally forgot about it the other day when I was writing my pre-Endgame entry, but if I hadn‚Äôt rushed myself, I probably would have said that I know the Quantum Realm must have something to do with the heroes coming because apparently, Dr. Strange has a lot to say about the Quantum Realm (Tom Holland once spoiled). But I wasn‚Äôt sure what. It was basically the main key. I will say though that I did not hear Dr. Strange say anything about the Quantum Realm in the movie though, so idk what that comment was about, Tom. Maybe when I watch it the second time. Who knows when though, because I have no friends. Anyway, they tried to use the stones, but Thanos said he used the stones to destroy themselves, so they no longer existed. With that, Thor killed him by slicing his head off. Then a rat saved the day five years later by running across Scott‚Äôs yellow van with the Quantum Realm machine contained inside and made Scott pop out of the Quantum Realm. No one saw that coming haha. Scott said it only felt like 5 hours, but it had been 5 years. That made him realize that if they could control the Quantum Realm, they could use it to go back in time. Idk how Scott figured that might be possible because it seems the only thing the Quantum Realm ever did was not keep track of time, but somehow this led to the Avengers realizing they could go back in time. They went back in time to recapture all the stones, which they somehow knew on the top of their heads where each one was and what year, and then all came back and then used the stones to snap everyone back. Unfortunately for them, when Nebulla and one other person that I‚Äôm forgetting right now went to Thanos‚Äôs place (I don‚Äôt remember the name) to get a stone, the Nebulla in the past sensed that there was another Nebulla there from a different time period (Nebulla is a cyborg), so then Thanos found out they were they and put together everything. The bad Nebulla switched with the good one and brought Thanos into the future with Gamora and current Nebulla, I believe. Then I‚Äôm not really sure what happened or where they were, but Thanos was trying to this time snap everyone away and then create his own people who weren‚Äôt unappreciative of his snap, he once again tried to fight all the still living Avengers and almost won, when all the others came back because the reversing the snap had worked. Then everyone was back, and they had a final fight against Thanos. Somehow amid the fight, Iron Man got the stones from Thanos without Thanos realizing, so when he snapped, nothing happened and then Iron Man snapped and made all Thanos and his bad guys disappear. Then Iron Man died.

I have to say; Marvel did a really good job being sure to surprise everyone and still have a proper closure. I feel like it has to have been a struggle because you want the movie to end the way it should where everyone is melancholy, but at the same time, you don‚Äôt want everyone to know what‚Äôs gonna happen. I read several fan theories before and I was pleasantly surprised that none of them were correct. Really no one could guess how everything would happen. No one saw Black Widow dying (which I was really sad about), no one saw Cap living in a different timeline until he grows old, no one saw Cap fighting his old self to get a stone, no one saw Thanos dying in the first like 10 minutes, no one saw years passing, no one saw Gamora coming into the future from the past, no one saw everyone -- every single hero, fighting Thanos again‚Ä¶., you get the idea. Just so much of the movie was unexpected, which made it amazing. And then there were all the references and small easter eggs in previous movies all came back in the end and the whole movie really felt like closure. It just makes me love MCU even more. I was surprised there was no ‚ÄúIn living memory in Stan Lee‚Äù at the end though. I am a bit confused though because I read an article recently saying that either Feige or the Russo Brothers had said that actually Far From Home is the last movie in Phase 4, which honestly doesn‚Äôt make much sense because it really feels like after Endgame should start a new era. All the main heroes are gone now, time to begin something new. There was even no after credit scenes in Endgame, so it really was like ‚Äòthe end.‚Äô Putting FFH in Phase 4 just doesn‚Äôt make much sense, so I hope that‚Äôs not true. I‚Äôm hoping that was just said to through people off about what time period the movie was from so that there were fewer Endgame spoilers. But idk. We‚Äôll see, I guess.

But overall, the movie was just awesome and very inspiring, and it had the right amount of humor, sad moments and melancholy feel and it really makes me wanna watch all those past Marvel movies since 2008, to catch up. I‚Äôm seeing the movie again next weekend and I already can‚Äôt wait.
Cinema Sins:

1. So, all Peter, Ned, MJ, Flash, Betty Brant‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre telling me they all happened to get snapped? I mean sure, I guess, it‚Äôs just a very convenient coincidence. Nonetheless, I‚Äôll allow it because I would rather they‚Äôre all in school together than all different ages.

2. If the Quantum Realm doesn‚Äôt keep track of time, how did Hope‚Äôs mom age in the Quantum Realm? She was gone for like 15 years maybe, but wouldn‚Äôt that just be like 15 hours in the Quantum Realm then? She should have come back looking the same as she did when she entered.

3. If all that going back in time does is create different timelines, they aren‚Äôt the Avengers just ruining their own lives in different timelines then? Does that not matter to them? What if someone‚Äôs life sucked, could they just go into the Quantum Realm and go back in time and then kill themselves in that time period and then just live on with their lives in that timeline now? I guess that‚Äôs sort of what Cap did.

4. Was there a time limit to how long everyone could be gone and get the stones by? Because they all arrived back at the same time somehow, although I don‚Äôt recall anything being arranged. Shouldn‚Äôt they all have been rushing a lot quicker if they had a time limit? Like Black Widow and Clint were sitting up there or Vormir with the Red Skull for how long?
5. If the stones are so powerful, then why didn‚Äôt each have a very costly price like the soul stone? How come it‚Äôs only the soul stone that is super protected like that?
6. Why was Cap the only one to go back? Returning them is just as dangerous as getting them, isn‚Äôt it? So why are they now much less cautious?
7. And how is Cap gonna inject that stone back into Jane Foster?

8. Where was Captain Marvel all that time? She helped them in the beginning and then dipped and then came back in the end. Was she just living in her own world that whole time, while all the Avengers were suffering?

9. How did Captain Marvel know where to save Iron Man and Nebulla? Fury started calling her, but then vanished and never had time to explain anything. I realize that she scours space looking for bad guys, but space is HUGE. Do you really want me to believe she just happened to find Iron Man in time? And that‚Äôs pretty lucky that Nebulla decided randomly to put him in the front seat of the spaceship then, right?
10. No ending quote recognizing Stan Lee.

I know a lot of people liked this movie, but imma be honest. It fell short for me. A lot of people respect Jordan Peele because of his old YouTube videos and his last recent/first movie Get Out. Get Out was a great movie. But just because Get Out was good doesn‚Äôt mean this one was too. I get ultimately what I disliked about it was that it put so much focused into getting out a message, that it lost its practicality (even in its fictional world). There were a bunch of holes in the story that just never got filled in by the end of the movie. I would overall give it 1.5/5 stars.

I guess one could say ‚Äúthis is a horror movie, they aren‚Äôt normally realistic at all, it‚Äôs just entertainment. The important part is that the message showed in the movie,‚Äù but I guess my frustration was the fact that it was Jordan Peele. He did so well before, so I walked in with high standards. The man is a genius, so I expected another genius movie. More personally, I prefer movies that are realistic in a fictional sense. What I mean by that is for example, in Harry Potter, they have wands and cast spells and do magic so obviously that is not realistic, but it follows a realistic sense in that if Harry point his wand at a cup and said that ‚Äúaguamente‚Äù spell that conjures water, the cup wouldn‚Äôt just disappear. If it did, that would be pretty unrealistic in even the Harry Potter world because they have their own physics which need to be abided by. If there were no rules, it would ruin the story completely because everything would just happen convenient to the plot and there would be no problems and then no story (and in some of the movies, that almost happened). So, I felt that Us didn‚Äôt even follow its own physics, which were mostly the same as ours. It was like Get Out in the fact that it was set in modern time and the people acted like humans and had realistic reactions when communicating, but where the two movies differed was that in Get Out, it‚Äôs like that story could have really happened. Everything was plausible (except for being able to put one soul in another‚Äôs head and having that work ‚Äì that was the fictional essence). The power of the movie was that it was real in story, practicality and sent a powerful message about our society. The same one Chris Washington was living in except for the racism was a little less discreet there with the black body switching. In Us, the movie couldn‚Äôt be imagined in real life at all. It had a message that related to our present world, but the fictional aspect didn‚Äôt show that message in a genius way that exemplifies our society like Get Out did. The whole idea just wasn‚Äôt realistic in the setting they set the movie up to be in. So that took away from the movie for me. It had nowhere near the power Get Out had and the cinema sins count just went way over the top. After watching the movie, I turned to Wayne (because I have no friends) and told him ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt get it‚Äù and he replied that he didn‚Äôt either. So that was a big turn-off for me. I don‚Äôt like a movie that is like a scavenger hunt to put the story together. I like it where it all makes complete sense once you finish the movie, but then you if you decide to look deeper, you can and maybe you will find a lot more, just like with Get Out. But the overall message is clear by the end and nothing is left questioned.

I think Peele was hinting that Jason had gotten switched too, most likely the last time they were there. I don‚Äôt know how it really could have worked logically, but the sand tunnels, the snapping at the end, he wasn't eating, he couldn't remember how to do the magic trick, he couldn't remember where the bat was, the family was commenting about his new vocabulary and I think at some point in the movie someone mentioned that Jordan hadn't been the same since the last time they were there, and he took the rabbit back with him at the end -- Jordan Peele is a genius so everything he puts in his movies is purposeful. I'm sure Jason didn't take back that rabbit just because he randomly wanted a pet rabbit from a place where someone tried to kill his mom. I think that last eye contact with them means that Jason somehow got switched too and had been tethered the whole movie. It does not rug me right to leave something completely open to audience opinion at the end of the movie though. Some people say Jason wasn‚Äôt a tether because that makes no sense and both theories are completely true. You can‚Äôt fully dispute either one. I have a feeling Jordan Peele is never gonna tell us his real intentions about Jason in fact, I don‚Äôt even know if he knows himself. So, I don‚Äôt appreciate that. It just leaves a big hole in the movie that one will never be able to satisfy.

So, what exactly was the message of this movie? I had no idea once I first saw it, but then after reading some explanations of the ending and the movie overall, it started making more sense. I saw what the movie was trying to say. I‚Äôm under the impression that the message of the movie is all about how it's not that there's a good side and a bad side, there's just a more fortunate side and a less fortunate side. The less fortunate side grew up without proper communication or food and had to kill rabbits to eat. They were mad that they had to live this terrible life while the others could live so much better, so that's why they came up and killed all the upper side. To get revenge for being left down there. An example is when Red switched with Adelaide, she wasn't crazy anymore. She didn't kill things and she talked English and lived a normal life with friends and family that she cared about very deeply. Just like a normal mother. This also explains why so many people‚Äôs ‚Äúkids being half-tethered‚Äù theory makes no sense. The kids being biologically half-tethered shouldn't do anything to them. It shouldn‚Äôt make them violent. No one is born violent. The tethered people living underground are just violent because they lived trapped in that small space being angry and killing rabbits all their lives. Because the kids didn't, they should not be violent or anything like the other tethers living down below. Red shows some signs because she used to live down there, but now she is mostly normal.
Cinema Sins:

1. They treat the escalator going down to the clone‚Äôs room like some type of automatic plot-convenient switching elevator. Like how is it always conveniently moving in the same direction as the person coming wants to go? It‚Äôs going up when Adelaide/Red wants to go up and going down when Adelaide/Red wants to go down.

2. If there‚Äôs only one person in the whole U.S that the government‚Äôs cloning goal was successful for, the likeliness that that one person is someone who has a family tradition of going to a cabin nearby the one entrance to the basement every summer is VERY slim.

3. If the ‚ÄúFind Yourself‚Äù attraction was no longer in use at the part, then why wasn‚Äôt it locked? If it was a secret government project, it surely would have been more protected/hidden even if it had failed.

4. When the clone family first got to the Johnson‚Äôs house, why did they just stand out there for so long? How long did they plan to stand out there before going inside? I get that they went there at 11:11, but was there any plan as to when they would all come inside?
5. Why were the clones able to tell where their original human was? That was never explained.
6. This is America, there would definitely be people with guns who would shoot down the clones before they got to them and killed them and their family.
7. You‚Äôre telling me that the boat motored away and then just came back by itself? *Queue Jeremy‚Äôs laugh*

8. I get that the clone sister is fast because she runs track, but shouldn‚Äôt the real sister be just as fast? The clone copied the sister‚Äôs movements, right? So how can she be faster than the real sister if they have ran just as much? Especially because the real sister had an appropriate diet and clone did not. And where did the clone practice anyway? In that small basement? That basement doesn‚Äôt look big enough for someone to be running track. Surely, she was running into walls then and should probably be dead from injury by now.

9. Exactly how many clones were made? The movie gives the idea that there‚Äôs one for everyone in the US because they make the line across America, but that basement for sure doesn‚Äôt look big enough to accommodate that many people and also have that much room for people to be walking around like they were. There would need to be sooo many bedrooms. And is there only one way out to the upper side of the world? Because if so, it would take a lot longer to get everyone the clone of everyone in the US up and out of that basement.

10. So, was that one guy on the beach just standing there with his arms out for hours/days just waiting for everyone else to kill their counterparts and come? Because I‚Äôm pretty sure that‚Äôs impossible to be holding your arms up like that for so long, even for a clone.

11. I really don‚Äôt get the whole Jason controlling his tether. In fact, I don‚Äôt get any of the controlling tbh. If the tethered were all controlled by their upper parts, then how did they escape the basement? How were they not being controlled anymore? Why was Pluto still being controlled but no one else was? And shouldn‚Äôt the real version be controlling the tethered? So okay maybe Jason was tethered (switched at some point), but still doesn‚Äôt explain why Pluto was the one being controlled still.

12. And Peele seemed to really be pushing hints that Jason was tethered at us but then how could he have learned English so fast? And why was the real Jason acting like a dog so fast? So, what was the story there? I don‚Äôt like how Peele left that unclear.

13. Logistically, how could this clone rebellion even happen? Like where did the funding for the jumpsuits and long scissors come from and how did Adelaide/Red communicate to the clones about what to do and what sizes everyone wears? They don‚Äôt speak any language.

14. So, what do the clones do now? They all escaped, killed their upper-selves and now they‚Äôre just holding hands across the country. Are they just gonna stay like that forever? How do they know when it‚Äôs time to stop? And why was everyone but Adelaide included in the Hands Across America? Did she just say, ‚Äúyou guys all do the holding hands part and I‚Äôll just stay down here in the basement‚Äù? I mean she couldn‚Äôt have known that Red was gonna come from the start because their plan originally went awry. They were gonna kill everyone at the cabin, but the Johnson‚Äôs got away. By then clones had already started holding hands.

15. And that gets me to what do the Johnson‚Äôs do now? Just live in America with a bunch of clones. They are all so happy they escaped, but don‚Äôt they realized that all their friends and family are probably killed now if the clones are killing their original? Their only option is to move to a new country now. Unless the clones just stay holding hands forever, then the Johnson‚Äôs can all live on earth all by themselves with all the money and food they want.

16. Why does Adelaide walk all robotic now? When she was walking, she was super calm and turned sharply. Not walking like a human at all. She is a human and even more, was never a clone so shouldn‚Äôt she be walking normally?

tech_reviews.title: Apple MacBook Air M2 Review (moving from Windows to Apple MacBook)

content.text: I bought the MacBook Air M2 in March 2023 when I learned that coding is a better experience on MacBooks. There are less issues with installations and the built-in terminal when using a Mac. And I have to say, I have not run into problems like I did on my HP Envy (Windows) device on the MacBook while coding. There are some things I like better about the MacBook, but then some things I like better about Windows devices. Btw, I‚Äôm using MacOS Ventura (from Windows 11 on my HP), and when I bought it in 2023, it was the latest MacBook Air M2 that one could get.
Looks / Build

The variant that I got isn‚Äôt very stellar in looks imo. It‚Äôs super flat and rectangular like a slab of cardboard. It doesn‚Äôt look very premium which is a little surprising to me for an Apple device. I wasn‚Äôt surprised about the looks/build when I got it though because I had tested this computer out at Costco a few weeks before getting it. The device is a dark bluish color (‚ÄòMidnight‚Äô I think is the official name). I can‚Äôt remember if I had color options or not when buying, but it‚Äôs not a bad color. I think this color and design might be a bit unique for MacBooks though because one tech friend I have said, ‚Äúwhat is that?‚Äù when I took my MacBook out and then another friend later said something similar to ‚ÄúApple makes black laptops?‚Äù I‚Äôm not super used to MacBooks so I don‚Äôt know what colors options they have had in the past. I think I‚Äôve seen like dark gray, light gray and maybe a pinkish color‚Ä¶. The computer itself is very thin, in fact, it‚Äôs the thinnest computer I‚Äôve ever had. It‚Äôs possible I might buy a case for it since it‚Äôs so thin. So, it doesn‚Äôt look fancy at all and doesn‚Äôt look very similar to other MacBooks I‚Äôve seen. It‚Äôs almost like someone else designed it and then gave it to Apple. I much prefer the build of my Dell XPS 13 and HP Envy x360.

The keyboard is alright. Nothing special. I think I prefer the keyboard to both my Windows computers better, but I don‚Äôt have any significant complaints about the MacBook keyboard. The two minor things are I hate are the mini arrow keys (like if you have room to make them bigger, why wouldn‚Äôt you make them bigger wtf. I keep missing the arrow keys because they are so small‚Ä¶pretty annoying), and the sound of the keyboard. I have never minded the sound while typing on the computer myself, but I remember I always used to hate the sound of other people typing on MacBooks at school, and I‚Äôm sure this one is no exception. I will note that right now, I choose to use my HP to type this review. I also will say, I haven‚Äôt gotten very used to either my MacBook keyboard or my HP keyboard, meaning I still make constant typing mistakes with them and reach for keys only to hit the key right next to the one I want‚Ä¶but I think that honestly just says more about me than the computers themselves.

Then, there‚Äôs getting used to the cmd/ctrl buttons being in different places. The cmd key on the Mac is basically the ctrl key on Windows, so they work similarly, but I think the key placement is better on Windows devices than on MacBooks. It‚Äôs a better feeling for me to be reaching from the bottom-left of the keyboard than right next to the spacebar (because the cmd/ctrl keys are normally paired with other keys to get certain functions). I think the placenent on the Mac has to do with having both the ctrl and cmd key, so they needed to position them in a way that was comfortable to press both of them at the same time for certain functions. I honestly don‚Äôt see the point in having both a ctrl and cmd key though. But at least the MacBook has 2 cmd keys unlike my HP ü§∑üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. This is a minor complaint, but I also don‚Äôt like the fn button for emojis. It‚Äôs laggy and doesn‚Äôt always work. I had to bookmark an emoji page on my browser now on copy emojis from because trying to use fn to make them appear was irking me too much. The Windows shortcut (Windows key + .) is a lot more reliable and never got to be annoying experience for me like on the MacBook.

The trackpad is fine. I had to get used to two-finger clicking rather than right clicking (even though I think I could change that in settings if I wanted to), but now that I‚Äôve gotten used to that, it‚Äôs not that bad. I‚Äôve started doing the two-finger clicking on my HP now too which honestly isn‚Äôt the best because it‚Äôs more of a hit or miss on that computer. It‚Äôs like sometimes it recognizes that I‚Äôve two-finger clicked and sometimes it takes it as a single-finger click. I think the trackpad on the Mac feels better when using it than the one on the HP Envy, and my old Dell XPS‚Äôs trackpad doesn‚Äôt even always work, so Apple wins that one.

The screen on the MacBook is taller than the screen on my HP and Dell and I do notice the difference a bit. It‚Äôs not a big change, but it is nice to have a bigger screen. I get all my laptops at 13‚Äù because they are cheaper that way and easier to travel with, but the 13‚Äù screen real estate on my MacBook Air is very pleasant. I do wish it had a touchscreen like my other devices have had, but it‚Äôs okay that it doesn‚Äôt. The only difference it really makes for me is when signing my signature on online forms and then testing out how my web applications would perform on mobile with touchscreens. I had to clone my code down to my HP and run my applications there to test the touchscreen screen experience because I couldn‚Äôt do that on the Mac.
Performance

The performance on the MacBook Air M2 is great. I have not run into any lag issues on the MacBook. No freezes or black screens as far as I can remember. The fan runs a bit sometimes, but definitely less than both my Dell and HP, so it is not a noisy computer or one that gets very heated.

One thing I‚Äôve noticed is that video sizes are smaller on my Window computer and Android devices than they are on the MacBook for some reason (I have not tested this with transferring files to iPhones). I transferred a video from my HP that was 552MB and on my MacBook it is now 579MB. I looked this up and apparently, it‚Äôs because media is measured a bit differently between the operating systems (Mebibytes vs Megabytes). Interesting. But it‚Äôs still the same size file, so that‚Äôs fine then.
Software

The software is ok. It‚Äôs hard being so used to Windows and then moving to Mac. There‚Äôs getting used to the individual window controls (close, minimize, full screen) being on the opposite side, but I think I‚Äôve gotten used to that one now. I actually think I prefer its location on the MacBook. It seems more logical on the left side.

Something I noticed right away when using the Mac is the scrolling. It‚Äôs opposite scrolling than what I‚Äôm used to on Windows devices. On Windows, you scroll up to go up and down to go down. On Apple, it‚Äôs the opposite. It has you scrolling down to go up and vice versa. This was a problem for me because I am so used to it being the other way, so I downloaded an application ‚ÄúUnnaturalScrollWheels‚Äù from ther0n on GitHub to fix this (no, this is not an ad). This made it so that scrolling is the same as on Windows devices for me. I have to manually turn the app/setting on every time I restart the computer, but it‚Äôs okay as long as my scrolling is back to ‚Äúnormal‚Äù after that.

Another thing I‚Äôve noticed, is it‚Äôs not as easy to split-screen on the MacBook as it is on Windows computers. With Windows, I can simply drag a window to the side of the computer to split-screen, but there‚Äôs just extra steps on the Mac. I can even do 4-way split-screening if I wanted to on my HP but cannot on the Mac. I also don‚Äôt like the switching between apps (window management) experience on the MacBook very much. I don‚Äôt mind the ctrl + left/right arrow keys to switch between full screen windows, in fact, I kind of like that option. But I don‚Äôt like all my open apps cluttering onto the taskbar whenever I minimize them. It just feels cluttery and messy to me and I don‚Äôt need all my open apps displayed like that. I know I can turn on the option of not having the apps go into the taskbar when minimizing them, but that‚Äôs actually just even worse because then I have to do the extra step of right clicking (or two-finger clicking actually on the Mac) an app on the taskbar and then reading the list of open windows combined with all their suggested windows and I don‚Äôt like having to read through everything to find my window every time. Again, it‚Äôs these small extra steps that become tedious when having to do them all the time and it makes a big difference when you don‚Äôt have to. I like being able to just hover over an app on my taskbar on my Windows computers and see the preview of all my open windows there. It‚Äôs easy to view, quick, and feels a lot less cluttered to me. Not even the cmd + tab is very helpful because it doesn‚Äôt show my open windows, and ctrl + up arrow only lets me switch between tabs that I have not minimized. I‚Äôve tried many different commands and settings, and nothing beats the multitasking of Windows computers so far. For me, Apple just needs to clean that up. (DockView is an application that can make window management similar to the Windows experience on Mac, but it‚Äôs third party and it costs $20+).

In general, the MacBook is a lot more command heavy than the Windows computers I‚Äôve used and since my memory isn‚Äôt great, it gets a little annoying having to constantly look up certain commands to do certain tasks. But once you get the hang of them (if I ever do), I imagine it‚Äôs probably a pretty fast and smooth experience, maybe even more so than with Windows for some people.

Lastly to note, I don‚Äôt know about Finder on the Mac. It runs faster than File Explorer does on Windows in my experience, but it‚Äôs not as advanced it seems. I don‚Äôt like how I have to press a button to make files organize themselves instead of the computer doing that automatically, and I don‚Äôt like how little info it shows about selected media. Like I can‚Äôt even view the frame rate of a video unless I open the video and go to some settings in the QuickTime Player application. And for VLC users, I can say from my own experience, VLC works better on Windows. It gets laggy on my Mac. QuickTime Player‚Ä¶does anybody like that sh*t?

Overall, I think the software is pretty good on this MacBook Air though. There have been multiple programs that I‚Äôve tried installing on my HP that did not go well that I was able to install on my MacBook Air with no trouble at all (all from the terminal), so that‚Äôs a win.
Camera / Sound

I noticed right off the bat when testing the MacBook Air, the speakers on it are WAYYY better than any Windows computer I‚Äôve used. Like you can really hear the bass and everything when listening to music on it. They sound rich and are probably the best speakers on any device (computer or phone) that I‚Äôve used so far. The camera is also the best camera I‚Äôve used on a laptop so far. When I switched from my HP to the Mac, someone I had weekly online meetings with told me that my sound quality was a lot better (there wasn‚Äôt this background noise and foggy sound like there was on my HP I guess) and that they could see me much more detailed now. I hadn‚Äôt realized the quality difference myself because I don‚Äôt have video meetings with myself, but apparently it was a big improvement.
Conclusion

In conclusion, I really like the MacBook Air. It does what I needed it to do and so I believe it was worth the buy. It‚Äôs different than my Windows devices, but that was expected. I knew there would be things I liked better about it and things I preferred more on Windows. I have not used any other MacBook computers, but I think this has been a good first experience and I‚Äôm glad to be part of the MacBook ecosystem now. I would recommend this device for Apple users, power users who aren‚Äôt gamers (because there are probably better gaming laptops specifically for that) or computer programmers.

Okay, so I got my Samsung Galaxy S9 in 2018 as a spontaneous gift from my dad when we went to an open house for UC Irvine at the mall. From then on, I loved that phone-- everything about it. The performance, features, customization‚Ä¶. I loved it so much that even when I got my Galaxy S20, I wanted to keep my S9. Now, I can say the S9 gave me a good four years of service, but it has worn down to the point where I believe I could no longer use it as my main driver if I wanted to in 2022. Here‚Äôs a deep dive into why.
Performance

The amount of ram this device had was always a strong point. I think I remember being amazed by how well the device‚Äôs memory was. But now in 2022, I‚Äôve noticed a couple of times where I open an app, and it has to restart. It happened only yesterday that I was typing a comment into YouTube and switched to my browser to look something up, and then when I switched back, YouTube refreshed, and I no longer had my comment (I had to retype the whole thing). I ran a quick speed test with my S9 and my iPhone 8 today, and the iPhone 8 won in all apps except Instagram, YouTube and OneNote and there were a couple of ties. The S9 struggled with a lot of lag when trying to open apps. The phone was once faster than the iPhone 8 I believe but definitely not anymore. For a memory test, the S9 had to do twice as many app refreshes as the iPhone 8 did. Some info to note is that the iPhone 8 was released in 2017 (and is currently running the latest and greatest IOS software, IOS 15). The S9 was released in 2018. The constant stuttering and lag are a regular ordeal for the S9 these days. I can‚Äôt do pretty much anything without having to deal with it which is the main reason I just couldn‚Äôt stay with my sim card in the S9.
Software

Another reason I no longer find this phone suitable as my main driver is because of the lack of software updates. In 2022, the latest Samsung One UI version is 4 (which still hasn‚Äôt come to my S20 yet in the time that I‚Äôm writing this review) which runs Android 12. Although, my S9 stopped receiving updates in 2020 so it is stuck on Android 10 and One UI 2. Because of the lack of updates, there are minor differences with how the S9 functions vs. my S20 or any Samsung running the latest software, and some of those differences I really value on my S20. For instance, on my S20, I can pin apps on the share screen. When I want to share a photo or file, I can pin the apps that I typically share stuff to at the top so that I don‚Äôt have to scroll through the list of options. Interestingly, my S9 used to be able to do this but lost this feature among one of its updates and that‚Äôs a shame because it was a feature I used frequently. Another small factor I miss when switching to my S9 is the newest gallery update. With the updated gallery app, I can edit photos, and then the photo will stay edited unless I revert it to its‚Äô original. On the S9, when I edit a photo, it creates a 2nd version of the photo, so I have two of the same photo, one edited and one not. Then I delete the original if I don‚Äôt want it which, typically, I don‚Äôt. That‚Äôs just one way the gallery app is more user-friendly with its latest updates, and it‚Äôs simple things like those that make the phone experience go from annoying to quick and easy. I miss these kinds of features whenever I‚Äôm using my S9 and now that I have them on the S20, it would be hard to ever go back to the S9 as a main driver.
Battery

The battery is just bad at this point. I have put a new battery in the phone twice now and the 2nd time it really didn‚Äôt seem to do much anyway. It drains like a funnel. Even at night when I‚Äôm not even using the phone, it will drain at least 10% by the morning. Important to note, this is all without having the sim card in. If the sim card was in the phone, I predict the phone would be unusable. I wouldn‚Äôt be able to take it out anywhere without having my phone run dead by the time I got home.
Camera

The camera is one department where the age of the phone isn‚Äôt showing as prominently, and I wouldn‚Äôt expect it to either. This phone had a great camera when I got it and still does. I don‚Äôt use it as much though because when I‚Äôm taking a picture, which isn‚Äôt very often, I‚Äôm typically taking them on my S20 or my iPhone 8 these days. But nevertheless, when I do take pictures, they are still quite satisfying. I have noticed missing the object eraser tool in the gallery app that the S20 has though. And there is minor shutter lag when taking a pic, but it doesn‚Äôt bother me.

I‚Äôve had this laptop for almost 2 weeks now I think, so here‚Äôs my review. I was pretty nervous before getting this laptop because it was significantly cheaper than the Dell one and the Thinkpad option that I could have gotten so I was scared it was gonna be a lot worse even tho I couldn‚Äôt necessarily see why from the specs. I was also afraid it was gonna look ugly bc it‚Äôs not a black keyboard like I used to have, and the HP Spectre looked ugly asf. I know worrying about the look of a laptop is the definition of a first-world problem, but if I‚Äôm gonna be using a laptop a lot for some years, I want it to look like smth I wanna use. So, I guess I‚Äôll split this review into categories.
Looks / Build

It looks sharp. The first thing I thought when unboxing it was that ‚Äúthis sh*t looks premium asf.‚Äù Just the look and feel of this computer make it seem worth the money. When I first used the laptop, I was not a fan of the keyboard. When writing my Pixel‚Äôs journal entry for the day I even said, ‚ÄúI prefer the XPS keyboard.‚Äù This one clearly felt different; I felt like the keys go down a bit more and it was kinda wearing my fingers out. After typing just a little bit with it my fingers were tired and I never got that feeling with the XPS not even when in 2018 when I got my first one. But now, after a couple of weeks, I‚Äôve gotten used to this keyboard to the point where I might actually prefer it. Typing on it just feels nice, it‚Äôs a satisfying feeling. I find myself purposely not answering some Askfm questions on my phone just so that I can type the answers when I‚Äôm in the mood to be on my computer. It took a bit of getting used to the new keyboard layout tho. Like for the first week of using it, I found myself consistently mistyping words bc my fingers weren‚Äôt used to where the keys are. On this computer, it‚Äôs like everything is shifted to the left from the XPS layout. They moved everything to have the buttons for the home, pg up, pg dn and end keys on the very right, so my fingers would automatically press one button thinking it was a different button after being used to the XPS layout or just any computer that doesn‚Äôt have dedicated space on the right for the home, end and so-on buttons. Now that my fingers are finally getting used to this setup tho, I‚Äôve found I really only have one issue with the keyboard. It was smth I was a bit nervous about but didn‚Äôt really know how it would really affect me. It‚Äôs the absence of the 2nd ctrl button. I miss it a lot. On this computer, they switched out the one on the right side for a fingerprint scanner and I used that one a lot when I was computer coding. I‚Äôve even considered only computer coding on my XPS just so that I can have that button again. Ik it‚Äôs picky, but it‚Äôs just hard having smth and then not having it anymore bc I got used to it. I really wish there was a way I could remap this 2nd alt key to be a ctrl key instead. There probably is some kind of difficult way if I download some weird software but whatever. I can deal. The last thing I guess I‚Äôve noticed about the keyboard is that bc it‚Äôs not black like the keyboards I‚Äôve always had in the past, it can get harder to see when there‚Äôs not a lot of light so I find myself using the backlit key options now more than ever. It‚Äôs fine tho, it works well‚ÄîI haven‚Äôt had a problem with it at all and it looks sexy anyway, but it‚Äôs just smth different than the XPS. One other thing I like about the build of this laptop is the trackpad. It‚Äôs just premium-feeling just like the whole laptop is all around. Clicking it is satisfying and it‚Äôs not like clicking plastic like my 2017 XPS was like. The clicker is not quite as silent as the XPS‚Äôs clicker, but it‚Äôs still fairly quiet and just feels more expensive. I am actually quite fine using this device w/o an external mouse (although I always will prefer the external mouse).
Edit (Feb. 2023): PowerToys from the Microsoft Store allows me to remap the right alt key to a 2nd ctrl key.
Edit (Jan. 2024): Half of the spacebar no longer works. Only responds when I press down on the right half.
Display

Now the display is a little different than my Dell. Things on it are a bit smaller, but for some reason, things also just seem sharper on the HP‚Äôs display. I don‚Äôt think this laptop is supposed to have a better quality than the Dell XPS (but I can‚Äôt remember for sure), but things just look a bit cleaner on this screen. I do wish the screen got a bit dimmer tho. I found myself a couple of times wanting smth a little gentler on the eyes and pressing the dimming button just to find that it‚Äôs already at its lowest setting. The XPS might even go dimmer than this one does. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve boosted the brightness up at all since I got it. But if I press the privacy screen setting it gets much dimmer so that‚Äôs like my lower brightness trick.
Performance

There‚Äôs not much to criticize in this department either tbh. There have been a couple of times I‚Äôve noticed where the screen will go black but then it will come back right as if nothing ever happened and there has not been an instance where it was unresponsive at all. The computer always seems to be working and those hiccups only really happened like twice. One thing I am noticing tho is that the computer does seem to run its fan quite a bit. Like today, I haven‚Äôt been able to use it at all without the fan going so if you‚Äôre someone who doesn‚Äôt really like that kinda white noise, this computer isn‚Äôt for you. The keyboard doesn‚Äôt get that warm, but I noticed the back of the computer where the heat seems to be coming out does get pretty warm. And today I haven‚Äôt even been doing that much use on it; I have a lot of tabs open in Chrome, then I have Spotify, Atom, Word and OneNote open, and I guess a couple of File Explorer folders. But the fan hasn‚Äôt stopped since I got on. I think the fan has a little more chill on the XPS but it‚Äôs okay.
Tablet

I have only tried the tablet feature on this thing once and it was pretty brief. I already have a tablet and this seems like a clunky a** tablet to use. I actually originally tried to get a laptop that didn‚Äôt fold into a tablet so that‚Äôs all a long way of saying that the 360x feature is not why I bought this. But since it does fold into a tablet I decided I might as well get the stylus jic I end up do wanting to use it in that mode. It‚Äôs aight. As soon as you fold it into a tablet it seems to recognize that you have gone tablet mode and automatically adapts. Writing with the stylus is nice although I found myself not wanting to touch the screen bc I was afraid of getting finger marks all over it and it‚Äôs hard to write with the stylus on this thing without touching the screen with my hand. One thing I have kinda noticed tho is that fingerprints don‚Äôt seem to show up on the screen that easily and maybe this is bc it is made for that sorta thing. So that‚Äôs kinda cool. Still, I did see some smudges stay on a bit so I didn‚Äôt really wanna mess with that much more. The laptop can fold into tablet mode while having devices plugged into it though so that‚Äôs nice.
Camera / Sound quality

In my experience, video and sound work just fine on this laptop. There‚Äôs nothing unexpected about the video/sound quality. As expected, the video quality is better when there is more light in the room and there‚Äôs a slight sound lag when watching videos using wireless earbuds. One thing to note is although you can turn off your camera and mic when you‚Äôre not using them, Zoom shows the screen recorder cam when your camera is turned off externally so you can‚Äôt really use it as a way to turn off your camera while using the app. That has bugged me a bit because I use Zoom quite a lot.

Edit (Apr. 2023): Apparently, the sound quality on the HP Envy x360 is very flaky and static-y for other people when using Zoom (and probably all other video meeting applications as well). It would be hard to hear me for other people when I talked. When I switched to Mac in 2023, people I talked to on Zoom told me the sound issues stopped.
Conclusion
So overall, not a bad laptop at all. Despite a few nitpicks, I can definitely see myself using it as a main laptop. It seems to be a great bang for its cheaper (but not cheap) buck as well.

Before I start with the whole reviewing, I‚Äôm gonna give a bit of background on my whole updating experience. If you don‚Äôt care, skip the first two paragraphs to go straight to the review part. I wasn‚Äôt planning on getting this update in all honesty. By observing YouTube videos, the new icons looked ugly, the rounded corners were overdone and therefore looked ugly and the biggest deciding factor for me: I would lose all Substratum features. The only factors that had me considering the idea were the gestures option, possibly faster speeds, and the dark mode, and honestly, I‚Äôm wasn‚Äôt super drawn to the dark mode. Typically, I like dark modes, but it didn‚Äôt seem to look all that great on the devices in the One Ui beta videos I watched. So, I decided I wouldn‚Äôt go for the update. As the ‚Äúupgrade‚Äù to One Ui date started approaching for the Samsung S series, I teetered on the idea a bit again, as I wanted to be updated like everyone else and have gestures and newer features, but I didn‚Äôt want to lose the features on my phone that I valued. I started considering rooting the phone because then my phone would be open to a lot more options and I would still be updated like all other S series users, but rooting comes with risks, which is why I have never pursued the option before on a phone (I rooted a tablet I had years ago back in like 2012). But in the last week, I really started considering it. Then, after a bit of searching, I found that since I have a contract with a carrier, I couldn‚Äôt root my phone. I also didn‚Äôt want to void the warranty because I found my warranty is still good till June, two months longer than I expected. You never know what might happen. I didn‚Äôt do too much looking after that, but I decided that, no, there‚Äôs no need to root it. I‚Äôm fine with how it is, and I won‚Äôt upgrade.

Well, that decision became pointless when One UI automatically updated to my phone. I was just using the phone when I put it down to do more studying and it just started updating. I tried to back out with my back button, and it didn‚Äôt work. I was going to be stuck with the update. As you can imagine, I was pretty pissed. Samsung didn‚Äôt even ask me if I wanted the update. They didn‚Äôt wait till I said it was okay to update, they just pushed it through whenever they felt like it. There should be a law against that for all devices.... This especially got me pissed when the update crashed my phone and repeatedly went to recovery mode. Because of all the overlays I had on my phone from Substratum theming, the update was not installing right and was continuously rebooting the phone. I couldn‚Äôt even unlock the device before it would reboot. My only option was to erase app data and go to Safe Mode and backup the device and then factory reset and restore everything. The only thing Samsung did right was backup my device automatically earlier that morning. Perhaps it does that whenever a new update comes. So that‚Äôs good on Samsung. If your gonna force updates to your phones, give automatic backups-- that makes sense. The only thing I ended up losing I think, is just some memos. Which I am mad at Samsung for. Ultimately, they should not update your phone unless you give it permission to. But when I say that‚Äôs the only data I believe I lost, I mean that. Substratum is now currently working on rootless Samsung Pie. I was like ‚Äúwell, there‚Äôs nothing really to lose now, so I might as well try putting these Substratum fonts on the phone just to see,‚Äù and to my surprise, it actually worked. I have all my old overlays and fonts on the phone, and I‚Äôve restarted it and even (accidentally) updated Andromeda and the theming is STILL working. Who knows how long this will last and maybe it will end up blowing up my phone later, but for now, it‚Äôs working. I need to make sure that I don‚Äôt update anything theming app or the phone itself because that could ruin everything. Google Play was having this problem yesterday where it was automatically updating apps even though auto-updates was off. Hopefully, that doesn‚Äôt last long because that should be against the law... One thing I noticed is when Google announced that they purposely disabled third party theming (fuck Google for that), they said they did it starting with an update in Oreo that was added into Android Pie. So maybe if that update didn‚Äôt affect my phone when it was on Oreo, it‚Äôs not gonna do it on Pie? I don‚Äôt know. We‚Äôll have to see. But I‚Äôm glad that‚Äôs it‚Äôs working now.

Okay now for the review part. I‚Äôm actually digging One UI. I‚Äôve used it for about 2 days now, so I can‚Äôt give a super detailed review (which I guess is good because no one would read this), but so far, I‚Äôm not hating it. Here are some categories and what I think of them on One UI:
Styling

The app icons aren‚Äôt my favorite, but they don‚Äôt look quite as bad as I thought they did through the computer screen. I suspected that the actual experience would be different than what you‚Äôre viewing on YouTube because the real thing is always better than just a video of it, but I still wasn‚Äôt sure I would like having it very much. Of course, after a while, you would get used to it, but still, I didn‚Äôt want to have to. I also still have all my old app icons that I changed using Awesome Icons, so it‚Äôs cool I didn‚Äôt lose those through the update. I don‚Äôt know if the app works on One UI yet or not so I might no longer be able to change them, but I‚Äôm not planning to delete those icons from the home screen so at least I have those. The rounded corners aren‚Äôt horrible either. I do think that the notification panel is a bit too thick for each individual notification and it would be nice to be able to reduce its sizing, but it reduces a little if you pick a smaller font. I also have my screen zoom on the lowest option (which isn‚Äôt very low) because, without that, everything felt way too clustered. The rounded corners actually don‚Äôt seem that much more rounded than the phone itself, which was one of the ugly designs I noticed in the YouTube videos. So, they are not that much overdone. The only place they are overdone in my opinion is in the gallery app. The album covers are a bit too rounded and there‚Äôs no padding, so they touch the edge of the screen and it looks pretty ugly in my opinion. I wish they had styled that better. I really don‚Äôt know whose idea it was to take the padding out of the albums. Don‚Äôt get how they liked that. Also, I‚Äôm not digging the new changes for Samsung Music. I never really liked that app design before and I‚Äôm still not feeling it now. For most of the apps, I like the new styling though. The calendar app looks dope now. The roundedness of the app is nice looking and the new set up just makes the app look really clean. I like it much better than the old design. Even the calendar widget is better. The rounded corners really make for a nicer look on the home screen. Moreover, Settings, Messenger, edge panel, Google app, Samsung Internet, Notes‚Ä¶. I think just in general, the rounded corners everywhere are making everything look very clean which wasn‚Äôt what I expected at all, so that‚Äôs thrilling.
Speed

The speed hasn‚Äôt improved or gotten worse from what I‚Äôve noticed. There was some hiccupping at first shortly after I had updated, mostly when going to multitasking screen, but that seems to have cleared up because I haven‚Äôt gotten any since. And this is coming from someone who uses a lot of third-party overlays over everything including the system ui. One thing I have never liked on my S9 Oreo was that whenever I press the share button, there is a lot of lag. There is still some lag when pressing it now, but I feel like there‚Äôs a tad bit less. Maybe the animations just make it look cleaner and less laggy. Idk. So, updating to One UI doesn‚Äôt seem to slow down your phone or speed it up. Hopefully, that lasts. Samsung doesn‚Äôt have a very good track record with that. We‚Äôre all hoping things are different with the S9, as they have been so far.
Battery

I haven‚Äôt noticed much difference with the battery. I saw some people say that they think the battery is lasting longer while others are saying they have found more battery drain. Personally, I think I would lean more on the drain side, but ultimately, I don‚Äôt notice that much difference I don‚Äôt think. I don‚Äôt constantly use my phone all day unless I‚Äôm in my room, which means I‚Äôm right next to a charger and I just plug it in whenever I feel like it so it‚Äôs not normally a problem for me. I also have this habit of thinking that the battery is too low any time it‚Äôs under 70%, so I charge more often than I have to haha. But it would be really nice to have a really good battery in a phone someday. I‚Äôm thinking of going for a Note someday in the future.
Multitasking

I do miss the card stack layout that we had before and I really think Samsung should have made it an option in settings, but this new layout is not completely horrible. You can‚Äôt see your other apps without scrolling now and that‚Äôs annoying, but the design that they choose for this not-as-appealing layout works. They do this thing where once you go to the multitasking screen from an app, it automatically shifts you to the left. I saw this first in a One UI review on YouTube and the reviewer said it was annoying and it looked annoying, but actually experiencing it myself, it‚Äôs not that bad. Typically, if you just left an app, you‚Äôre not gonna go straight back to it. Otherwise, why exit it in the first place. Especially why go to the multitasking screen if you‚Äôre not gonna multitask. So, it‚Äôs kind of helpful for it to be shifting like that. You‚Äôre either going back to the app that you last opened, which is probably what most people do, so it‚Äôs a helpful feature or you‚Äôre opening something else that you opened earlier so it‚Äôs giving you a little boost to get there. I do wish they had the option to go to the home screen from that with having to 3D touch the home button though. Like on iPhones you just tap somewhere out of the recent apps and it takes you to the home screen. Either way, it‚Äôs not that bad at all, at least not for me.
Features

Not many features were lost with One UI and they did add some new ones. There‚Äôs dark mode, which I tried, but I‚Äôm personally not digging it much. I‚Äôve heard a lot of other people online say they think it‚Äôs beautiful, so my word isn‚Äôt really the best to take into account here, but I just don‚Äôt like it much. I think it‚Äôs more of a personal preference that I generally prefer the white interface on apps. It just looks cleaner to me. But for colors, black any day. As anyone who knows me knows (so, no one), black is my favorite color. #MatteBlackEverything #MarquesBrownlee But on apps, the white interface is where it‚Äôs at. Except for Keepsafe. Dark theme is better there. Anyway, the gestures are nice. I‚Äôve been using them all day and I think they are nicer to navigate with than the buttons, but I do like the buttons. I wish they still have the little dot on the left where I could choose if I wanted the buttons to be permanently on the screen on not when I have the button option selected. I do like the new One UI navigation buttons better than Oreo‚Äôs, but I used neither because I have a Substratum overlay making my navigation bar the stock Android Pie navigation instead. I like the pill. It‚Äôs sophisticated looking if you know what I mean. But the gestures are simple to use, and I‚Äôve been working with them nicely. I really like having that option. That was the biggest factor that made me consider updating to One UI in the first place. Substratum was on a higher tier for me though, so I ultimately choose the gestures were not worth it. Now I have both which is something pleasant in my life after knowing I failed a math midterm today along with the other hundred things that make my life + life in general shitty. I guess just this one little One UI + Substratum pro doesn‚Äôt make up for it at all, but whatever. I need something that makes me smile a little bit. Additionally, some new features I‚Äôm liking is home screen option to lock apps in their place so they can‚Äôt be moved around and the new lock screen option where you can set it to icons only. I think it looks cleaner than having all those notifications hanging down and now people can‚Äôt read my notifications if they pick up my phone, so that‚Äôs nice. Well, unless they press the icons and swipe down, but that might not occur to them. Plus, no one would probably touch my phone without asking anyway. There‚Äôs the option to make apps more transparent when using popup mode. There‚Äôs also adaptive brightness now, which I haven‚Äôt really noticed much of yet, but I‚Äôm curious to keep using it and see how I like it. Some features they did lose though that I used to use other than the left-hand dot for the nav bar, is the option to make apps not have the background on the home screen icons (icon only option) and the option to change the color of the navigation bar.
Camera

I‚Äôm not a big camera person so I don‚Äôt take a lot of photos and I don‚Äôt really care about my photos being the best of quality. I just need to be decent quality so one can clearly see the photo and not blurry. One issue I‚Äôve always seemed to have with my S9 and I think with my S6 too, is that if you shake the camera at all while you‚Äôre taking a photo, the photo comes out blurry, which has been really annoying, but so far with a little bit of testing, that hasn‚Äôt been the case on One UI. I haven‚Äôt really tested it out too much, but I just felt like the photo looked clearer. The new design of the app looks a lot nicer too and is just cleaner, like with many other apps. I‚Äôm really digging the new camera.

So overall, I feel like I‚Äôm really enjoying One UI. It was a pretty big frustration at first, especially with the factory resetting and having to restore everything and re-login to apps, but then it was like having a new phone. I haven‚Äôt really lost anything (except some memos) and most everything looks a lot better than before. I‚Äôm glad I got the update and I totally recommend it, although if you don‚Äôt already have Substratum downloaded and you decide you want it later after you install One UI, it might not work for you, in fact, I‚Äôm guessing it probably won‚Äôt. But who knows then because I was guessing it probably wouldn‚Äôt work for me with it preinstalled, but it did anyway. For anyone who might be unsure about the update, get it. You won‚Äôt regret it. Or at least I‚Äôm not. You might, I guess. But I‚Äôm not.

tech_reviews.title: Dell XPS 13 9360 (after 1-year)
content: Last year I really wanted this laptop. Getting it was like the make or break of my Christmas (although it wasn't Christmas when I ended up getting it). I was just tired of having the old laptops that hardly worked and crashed and were super slow: my Thinkpad from Girls Who Code and the Samsung one I bought when I was 12. When I found out I was getting the computer after some snooping around (because my impatient ass was being impatient), I started looking up YouTube reviews on the computer. This is when I found out about something called ‚Äúcoil whine,‚Äù that apparently the computer tends to have a big issue with. I started kicking myself for not watching these reviews sooner, as I had only done some Google searches and liked how Eli‚Äôs computer (the same one) worked. It was called the best laptop of 2017 by many websites, so I figured it would be great. Naturally, I began to freak out about possibly getting coil whine on my new computer. It was too late now to look for a new computer. Not just reviewers, but people in the comment sections were complaining about coil whine too. It was the first thing I checked for once I got the computer. I‚Äôve had the computer for almost a year now and still, you cannot hear the coil whine at all unless you put your head on top of the keyboard (which nobody does), so that ended up not being a problem. But the computer isn‚Äôt problem-free even if the coil whine was not an issue.

The first thing I noticed was that the keyboard isn‚Äôt very comfortable. It was a lot smaller than I was used too, although that‚Äôs just me picking the 13 in over the 15 in (so keep that in mind if you‚Äôre thinking of switching from a 15 in or more to something smaller My fingers felt crammed asf while typing. I‚Äôm used to it now though). The keys are hard and don‚Äôt press down very much, making your fingers hurt faster after typing for periods of time. The keys have become looser throughout the year, but still, I think I would probably prefer the Mac keyboard which I‚Äôve heard is very comfortable. The backlit keyboard is definitely nice to have, but I‚Äôve noticed recently that it doesn‚Äôt turn on when I move around a connected mouse. It doesn‚Äôt stay on permanently, it goes off after a few seconds which makes sense -- saves battery. But the only way to make it turn on is by pressing the keys and since you can‚Äôt see the keyboard, you have to randomly press a key (unless you can locate where the key is in the dark) and then delete it after whenever you want to start typing. I swear it used to turn on when you wiggled the mouse. I don‚Äôt know If this is a bug that can be changed or what‚Äôs happening. I‚Äôm sure I can probably make the backlit keyboard stay on permanently in the settings somehow, but I feel like that‚Äôs wasteful and the keyboard should just be working better without having to tweak the settings.

I quickly found out after getting it, that my laptop had this bug where it would crash and tell me it needed to restart. I had to constantly save my work or hope the computer saved my work because I never knew when it was going to decide to randomly crash on me. I dealt with this a few months before finally doing a thorough search for how I could fix the problem. All it seemed to take was one simple update. So, I did that thinking ‚Äúwhew, now I won‚Äôt need to go through this again.‚Äù Unfortunately, though, it still crashes on occasions. Everything goes blue and it tells me I have to restart the computer. Then I lose everything. I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs ever going to completely go away.

Another issue I hate is the trackpad. I only learned this year that I could scroll up and down using the trackpad (which is completely my fault, I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs a common computer thing that I just was oblivious to all this time) and now I use it to scroll quite a bit. About 30% of the time when I‚Äôm using it though, it does this weird thing where it either takes me to my recent tabs screen or to the home screen. The reason it does this is that if you put 3 fingers on and swipe up, it goes to recents. If you put 3 fingers on and swipe down, it goes home. But the trackpad is so jumpy that it‚Äôs like it had no control. It will do those actions even if I use 2 fingers. I just want to scroll up and down and it‚Äôs annoying being taken somewhere else that I did not ask to be. I think the trackpad is a common issue. I‚Äôve seen a comment or two about it on YouTube.

Moreover, there‚Äôs the brightness. It doesn‚Äôt get as low as I would have liked. It has Night Light (blue filter) which I typically keep it in all day because I‚Äôm always tired, but it doesn‚Äôt get very dim. I think this is kind of common for a lot of Windows laptops (but don‚Äôt quote me on that because that might not be true). I‚Äôve also heard a lot on YouTube about the sound quality not being great, but that‚Äôs something I have not noticed to be an issue. The sound, at least on my computer, has always sounded fine ‚Äì loud and clear.

I was studying for a final earlier this month with a ‚Äúfriend‚Äù and a few of her friends and one of us happened to have the same laptop. We bonded for all of about a minute because we both agreed how much it sucked. Okay, it doesn‚Äôt suck, but it‚Äôs not all it‚Äôs cracked up to be if you‚Äôre watching or reading reviews that say it‚Äôs the best. And she brought up how she tried to return it and had issues with the support service. So apparently, I‚Äôm not the only one to have issues with this laptop that weren‚Äôt just coil whine.

All this being said, it‚Äôs not a complete bust. As reviews said, it is very fast. I‚Äôve had some issues with staying connected to the Wi-Fi a lot in my house, but I think that‚Äôs more of a ‚Äúmy house‚Äù problem than the computer. It hasn‚Äôt been an issue at my school. It heats up sometimes, but never too much. The screen does look nice (except like I said, I keep it on Night Light all the time anyway) and it does have the Windows perks. Then again, there‚Äôs random crashing/restarting, uncomfortable keyboard, annoying trackpad, not the best company support, backlit feature not working right and lack of brightness controls, which can be annoying if you‚Äôre up late at night.

You can find a lot of reviews on YouTube for this computer and if you look into the comment section, I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll read a lot about coil whine being a common issue, but this is my take on the laptop. We all have different experiences so maybe I‚Äôm just unlucky, but I‚Äôm just here to warn for whoever‚Äôs going for this computer, do so with caution. This is what you could possibly face. Of course, it‚Äôs still a fine working computer and we should probably all consider ourselves spoiled to even have technology like this in the first place, but getting past that, it‚Äôs not the best laptop you could go for. I wish I could have read (or watched) something more like this in reviews when I was looking. I would have probably gone for something else if I had.

vs.title: Apple vs Google vs Spotify vs Napster

content.text: I‚Äôve used all four of these music apps very intensely on both IOS and Android and here is my review/comparison on each of them. First, I‚Äôll say that all of them require accounts so the music will sync to any device as long as you login to your account. Furthermore, they all have the capability of downloading songs for offline use, although they download them into their own proprietary formats so that if you logout or unsubscribe, you can no longer access your downloaded music. They all have support for creating and sharing/publicizing playlists and makes their own in-app playlists for the most popular music of the current day, the year, different moods and different genres. People who don‚Äôt own the music service cannot view a shared playlist though.
Apple Music

For me, Apple Music is the best on IOS. I like how a user can move music that‚Äôs stored on their computer (mp3 or avi) into Apple Music through iTunes on the desktop and although it won‚Äôt match to a song in Apple Music, it will still sync across devices. Apple Music has a good range of music and lets users customize their playlist cover. It can has a nice organized looking interface, but I also feel like the part most people use, the page with all the user‚Äôs music is crammed into one small area and then there‚Äôs several additional pages that could easily be combined to make a much cleaner looking app. Like the ‚ÄúFor You‚Äù, ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù and ‚ÄúSearch‚Äù pages can all be one page and then the app would have more room to breathe instead of feeling like all these extraneous features crowding my space. What I don‚Äôt like so much about Apple Music is how it how it runs its playlists. The only way you can sort them is through the desktop application which is a pointless limitation. I feel like organizing your playlists is a must because it makes it a lot easier to find the music in them when they are very long. Another annoying thing about Apple Music playlists is that there‚Äôs no scroll bar to scroll through long playlists so you have swipe up for a really long time to get the bottom if there‚Äôs a song you want to see at the bottom.

While Apple Music is my favorite to use on IOS, it‚Äôs not my favorite on Android because of course Apple had to mess up their app for Androids. Several of the album covers refuse to load when they appear perfectly fine on IOS and same for several artist pictures. I‚Äôve tried restarting the device, updating the app, logging back into my account, closing out the app, and nothing‚Äôs worked except uninstalling the app and reinstalling it and then all that does is give me the album and artist art for all my preloaded music but doesn‚Äôt guarantee what I add later will have it. I‚Äôm not gonna reinstall the app after adding new music each time because then I have to redownload all my music each time which takes a while.
Pros:
User can upload their own music files
Customize playlist cover
Tells you when you‚Äôre about to add duplicates into your playlists
Dark mode option
Crossfade music option
Highlights most popular songs in albums
Includes syncronized lyrics
Cons:
Can only crossfade music on desktop
Can‚Äôt scroll through long playlists very easily
Not all album and artist pictures load even when Apple Music does have pictures for them (Android)
App interface is crowded with pages that I think can easily be combined to take up less space and make app seem less hectic
Google Music

I‚Äôll say straight up that Google Play Music is the application here that I‚Äôm least familiar with and I don‚Äôt have a subscription for it. Waaay back I used to use it with my Nexus 7 and now I use it for YouTube downloaded music, but basically, I‚Äôve always used it for storing my personal music on rather than playing any music from the app. From what I have experienced with Google Music, it‚Äôs easily the worst out of four music services for me. I don‚Äôt like its interface at all, and I have to cache my personal uploaded files on the app before I can listen to them offline. The interface looks messy and unfinished. I really dislike how when playing a track, the album cover shows up all zoomed in in the app so you can only see part of it and sometimes because of the unnecessary zooming, the part that you can see is blurry‚Ä¶.like who‚Äôs idea was this?? Google Music is like Apple Music where you can upload your own tracks, but you can only manually transfer your files through an extension on Google Chrome rather than having its own web application. Perhaps the Chromebook has its own desktop application, but not on Windows. Another thing I don‚Äôt like about Google Music is how focused it is on radios rather than playlists. I would rather have a playlist where I can see all the tracks rather than a radio where I have to skip through songs.
Google Music is one of the reasons I couldn‚Äôt switch fully to Google products. They have me effed over with that app. No Pixel or Chromebook for me.
Pros:
User can upload their own music files
Cons:
Interface is dirty asf
No desktop application
Can‚Äôt scroll through playlists very easily
Focuses too much on radios rather than playlists
Napster

Napster is the 2nd worst out of the four in my opinion, in fact, I hardly use it anymore now that I have Spotify and Apple Music. The main reason I stopped using Napster is probably because the app was always so laggy. It‚Äôs not a device problem because it‚Äôs been true for my Samsung, iPhone SE, iPhone 8 and PC. All of them open the app slowly and the app just performs laggy and it‚Äôs frustrating. Moreover, scrolling was just pure annoying on an Android device because I had some of my longest playlists on that app and the only way to scroll was by swiping up for a long time. Unlike the other two, there is completely no way to sort your playlist‚Äôs. You can sort it manually, but no one wants to do that especially with long playlists because that will take hours. I also think Napster‚Äôs competition, Apple Music and Spotify, have more music options overall. I think I tend to find more of the less popular available on Apple Music and Spotify more often than Napster, although Napster does seem to have more clean version options than Spotify.
Pros:
Easy to scroll through long playlists (IOS)
Customize playlist covers
Cons:
App is very laggy even on the desktop
Can‚Äôt sort playlists at all
Scrolling through long playlists is difficult (Android)
Spotify

Spotify is probably my favorite out of the four music services. The only things I don‚Äôt like about it is its dark interface and that you can only upload playlist covers through the desktop application. Although, I will say that I believe the Android version of the app is better than the IOS one. The Android version can scroll through large playlists easily with a sidebar unlike IOS which you have to do the repetitious scrolling up, and none of its settings are hidden. The latter remark was kind of out of spite because IOS has the capability to sort playlists, it‚Äôs just kind of hidden. Idk why they didn‚Äôt put it with the rest of the options (the three dots on the top-right. Another thing I love about Spotify is that it connects to devices so that you choose what device to stream on no matter which device you have the app open on so I can control which songs I‚Äôm listening to on Spotify through my laptop even if the earbuds I‚Äôm using to listen are connected to my phone. Lastly, I don‚Äôt know why a music app wouldn‚Äôt have a Find in Playlist button, but Spotify seems to be the only one to get that right.
Pros:
Sorts playlists
Find in playlist
Customize playlist covers
Crossfade songs option
Includes syncronized lyrics
Easy to scroll through long playlists
Connects to all devices so that you choose what device to stream on no matter which device you have the app open on.
Cons:
Does not have song genres
Permanently dark interface
